newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian man stole from guest to pay for wedding.
newsitem.headline: Australian man stole from guest to pay for wedding.

text.p: An Australian conman who paid for his wedding reception with a cheque stolen from one of his guests was described on Friday as a "predator" by a judge who sentenced him to five years in jail.
"You have added new meaning to the word contemptible," judge Patrick Shanahan told Nektario Zafiratos, who had pleaded guilty to 44 fraud, forgery and theft charges in Brisbane's District Court.
The court was told Zafiratos, 24, had stolen the cheque from the guest and used it to pay for a lavish wedding reception last June at a golf course resort on Queensland state's Gold Coast.
The next day Zafiratos stole the guest's car, which was later found abandoned and extensively damaged in the neighbouring state of New South Wales.

Zafiratos's marriage ended two months later when he was taken into custody after a crime spree which saw him use invalid cheques amounting to A$150,000 (US$115,500) to pay for a sports car, jewellery, clothing and the services of a prostitute.
He also ran up a debt of A$1,300 on a former girlfriend's credit card, which he paid off with a cheque he stole from her.
Shanahan said Zafiratos had also lied in telling his barrister he was enrolled in a New South Wales university.
"It's in the community interest you be detained in prison for a considerable period to protect the business community from predators like you," Shanahan said.
The court was also told Zafiratos's relatives had offered to buy him a real estate business when he was released from jail. (A$1 = US$0.77)
